U of L women rout Belmont 95-35

Moore leads Cards with 17 points

U of L women rout Belmont 95-35

Steve Jones, swjones1@courier-journal.com 11:28 p.m. EST November 20, 2014

Louisville's Shawnta' Dyer goes up and over the Belmont defenders to knock down a shot. Nov. 20, 2014(Photo: Scott Utterback/The CJ)

10 CONNECT 24 TWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

The University of Louisville women's basketball team dominated every facet of the game, got crippling scoring runs in both halves and didn't let Belmont attempt a single free throw in a 95-35 blowout at the KFC Yum! Center on Thursday night.

Freshman Mariya Moore continued her hot start to the season with 17 points as the No. 12 Cardinals (3-0) won by the eighth-largest margin in school history and kept the crowd of 7,404 entertained.

Coach Jeff Walz talks about the Cards victory over Belmont.

It's an impressive result against a Belmont team that lost by only seven points at Vanderbilt last week and is predicted to win the Ohio Valley Conference.

"I thought we played for 40 minutes, and I thought we didn't quit," Louisville coach Jeff Walz said. "When you get up 40 sometimes, your kids can be like, 'Oh, it's over; we're going to win,' but I thought we kept attacking and that's what I wanted to see."

The Bruins (0-3) were done for after having three more turnovers (20) than points in the first half. After trailing 8-3 early, U of L used a 30-2 first-half run to take a 31-point halftime lead, then piled it on with a 25-6 run late in the second half.

"When we watched them against Vanderbilt, they definitely seemed like a challenge, and they were really good," Moore said. "But I think it was just that we had a week to prepare and find out their tendencies and try to shut them down as much as possible."

Sara Hammond had 13 points and seven rebounds for the Cards, and Shawnta' Dyer, looking sharp after missing most of last season with injuries, made all five shots from the floor in adding 12 points. Myisha Hines-Allen and Emmonnie Henderson also scored 12 each.

The beating was thorough from start to finish with U of L outscoring Belmont 48-17 in the first half and 47-18 in the second, and the game was lopsided statistically in category after category.

A few numbers that stood out.

*Belmont stunningly attempted no free throws. Through the end of last season, that had not happened in a women's game nationally since Winthrop shot none in a 51-34 loss to Coastal Carolina on Jan. 17, 2009. Louisville, on the other hand, made 18 of 25 on free throws and was whistled for only nine personal fouls.

*All 11 available U of L players scored as the Cards shot 59 percent from the field. Belmont shot 27 percent.

*U of L outscored Belmont 60-6 in the paint as the Bruins shot 7 of 26 from both two-point and three-range.

*Belmont had just one more point than it did turnovers (34). Louisville scored 48 points off those giveaways.

Things actually started well for the Bruins, who are coached by former U of L assistant Cameron Newbauer. Taylor Mills made two early threes for an 8-3 lead after two minutes, but the Cards rang Belmont's bell after that.

"We all knew we were better than that," Moore said. "There was no reason for them to be able to come out there and do that after we'd been preparing for this."

Dyer came off the bench to score eight points and U of L turned up its full-court pressure during the 30-2 run, which included 24 straight U of L points over more than nine minutes. Belmont's Jordyn Luffman-Hartsfield ended the drought with a 3-pointer to make it 33-13 at the 6:46 mark, but the Cards were well en route to a rout by then.

"We played really good defense," Henderson said. "I think this was probably the best game that we've played defensively if you ignore the first two threes."

Henderson, who battled foul trouble as a freshman but has improved her conditioning and knowledge of the game as a sophomore, wasn't aware that Belmont had shot no free throws until a reporter asked her if she'd ever seen that in a game before.

"No, because normally, I'd be fouling them," she said with a laugh. "(This year) I understand the game more, so I know where to be at a certain time and not make up for something in a spot I'm not supposed to be."

While Henderson is improving in Year 2, Moore is shining in Year 1. She finished 6 of 10 from the floor, 4 of 4 at the foul line and had four rebounds, two steals and no turnovers in 26 minutes. Moore's averaging a team-high 17 points through three games, and Walz said she was solid at the top of U of L's 1-2-2 press.

Moore and Hines-Allen are the first U of L freshmen to score in double figures in their first three games since Jazz Covington in the 2003-04 season.

"She's very efficient for us," he said. "… She's not lightning quick. She's not out there with the best handles of anybody on the floor. But she just figures out a way to get things done, and that's really what impresses me most."

Steve Jones can be reached at (502) 582-7176 and followed on Twitter at @SteveJones_CJ.
